With this update, the company is launching new Apple Intelligence features, including the ability to remove objects from photos. The feature, called Clean Up, lets users identify and remove an object from the photo without affecting the picture. The system uses AI to generate background when you remove an object from an image. Apple said that the system understands even shadow or reflection of an object and

content.headline: Berkshire Hathaway cut Apple stake to have 'margin of safety'
content.summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-B, BRK-A) trimmed its stake in Apple (AAPL) by over 50% at the beginning of August. Berkshire Hathaway shareholder and Scharf Investments managing director Eric Lynch joins Market Domination to discuss the move and what the firm may do with the cash. Lynch explains that consumers and investors shouldn't be concerned about the move. Rather, he sees it as a testament to Buffett's commitment to having a margin of safety: "Look, it's a great company, but he bought it in 2016 at 10 times earnings. He's cut it over half when it's been trading above 30 times earnings. It hasn't moved its sales and its operating income level on the aggregate in almost three years, so he's worried about the margin of safety there." He adds that with this new cash flow, Buffett is "finding places to play," but ultimately is "waiting for better valuation." Lynch notes that Berkshire recently bought Chubb (CB), an insurance company, explaining that insurance premiums are increasing about 10% yearly. In addition, Buffett has identified several lucrative opportunities in Japan. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Market Domination. This post was written by Melanie Riehl

content.headline: Should you rush to buy the new iPhone 16 or can you wait?
content.summary: Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 16 launch event is just weeks away. On September 9, the tech giant will unveil its latest iPhone generation alongside the latest Apple Watches and AirPods. Should tech consumers run to the Apple Store upon release or wait to go out and spend on a new device? CNET editor-at-large Bridget Carey joins Wealth! to talk about the best consumer tech deals ahead of the Labor Day Weekend and as retailers shift focus farther down the road to the holiday season. While you may want to upgrade some of your tech, Carey advises consumers to be cautious about Apple (AAPL): "There's going to be an Apple event soon, just two weeks. Apple is going to be revealing new gadgets, and so I would say if you're going for like a brand new phone, no. But it's a great time for a sale if you don't care about having the newest stuff because retailers have to sell their inventory, so they're going to discount all the current earbuds and the other gear like old phones." For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Wealth! This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

content.headline: Apple's Market Share Poised To Gain, GenAI And iPhone 16 Lead the Way: IDC

content.headline: IDC raises annual global smartphone shipments forecast on GenAI optimism
content.summary: IDC expects shipments to grow 5.8% to 1.23 billion units in 2024, up from its previous forecast of 4% growth to 1.21 billion units.  "Although GenAI smartphones are relatively new in the market, premium flagships will continue to adopt GenAI features to help separate them from the pack," said Anthony Scarsella, research director with IDC's Worldwide Quarterly Mobile Phone Tracker.  At its developers conference in June, Apple unveiled a series of AI features for its operating system under the name "Apple Intelligence".

content.headline: Apple’s CFO Change Looks Smooth. Who Comes After Tim Cook Is More of a Problem.
content.summary: Apple looks to be orchestrating a relatively painless changeover for its finance chief.  Luca Maestri will step down as the long-serving chief financial officer next year after more than a decade in the role but will stay on in a reduced role.  This will be an inevitable reminder that  Apple  needs to do some succession planning for CEO Tim Cook.

content.headline: Apple Names New CFO. The Stock Is Down.
content.summary: Apple  said Kevan Parekh will step into the chief financial officer role on Jan. 1, succeeding current CFO Luca Maestri, who will continue on at the company.  Parekh is currently vice president of financial planning and analysis.  Apple stock was off 0.6% in premarket trading.

content.headline: Why Apple's iPhone 16 might not be enough to drive sales
content.summary: Apple (AAPL) is set to host its iPhone 16 launch event on September 9, with investors eagerly awaiting the unveiling of the next generation of smartphones, Apple Watches, and AirPods. Maxim Group managing director and senior consumer internet analyst Tom Forte joins Morning Brief to discuss the potential impact of this launch on the tech giant. Forte notes a specific challenge facing Apple this year: while the company will introduce new hardware in its latest iPhone upgrade cycle, consumers will need to wait for the updates related to Apple's artificial intelligence software dubbed "Apple Intelligence." Forte explains this could potentially delay sales for the tech giant in the near term as consumers might hesitate to purchase new devices until the software is released. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Angel Smith

content.headline: Here are some of the challenges Apple's next CFO will face
content.summary: Apple (AAPL) has announced new succession plans, with longtime CFO Luca Maestri set to be replaced by the company's current Vice President of Financial Planning. Kevan Parekh, will assume the CFO role effective January 1, 2025. Maxim Group managing director and senior consumer internet analyst Tom Forte joins Morning Brief to discuss the implications of this change on the tech giant. Forte commends Maestri's ability to return value to shareholders through dividends and buybacks, expecting Parekh to continue this approach. However, he notes that Parekh's main challenge will be navigating ongoing antitrust lawsuits. "These are challenging times for Apple on multiple fronts," Forte explains, citing increased regulation, EU scrutiny, and growing competition in China. Despite the succession, he expects "the overall strategy to remain." While acknowledging the significance of this leadership change, Forte believes "the bigger question" is when Apple will change its CEO. He describes Tim Cook as "the posterchild" type of CEO that follows a founder, suggesting his eventual succession will have more substantial implications for investors. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Angel Smith

content.headline: Affirm Earnings Are Soon. Its Apple BNPL Deal Will Be in Focus.
content.summary: Apple  has built a sprawling ecosystem of products that all work together—from the iPhone to the  Apple  Watch to the iPad.  At its Worldwide Developers Conference in June, Apple announced a partnership that will launch later this year with the Buy Now, Pay Later company.  Affirm’s payment products are expected to be available to Apple Pay users in the U.S. Shortly after, Apple scrapped its own Buy Now, Pay Later service barely a year after it made its debut.

content.headline: Apple CFO Luca Maestri to transition into new role in 2025
content.summary: Apple (AAPL) CFO Luca Maestri is set to step down from his role at the beginning of 2025 and will transition into a new executive role on Apple's Corporate Services team, his C-suite role to be filled by Apple Vice President of Financial Planning and Analysis Kevan Parekh. Yahoo Finance host Josh Lipton joins the Morning Brief team to discuss Maestri's achievements at Apple and what Parekh could bring to the table in his new position. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.
